newsitem.title: BELGIUM: SGB CEO says SGB shares undervalued.
newsitem.headline: SGB CEO says SGB shares undervalued.

text.p: Philippe Liotier, chief executive officer of Belgian holding company Societe Generale de Belgique SA (SGB), said on Monday shares in his group were undervalued.

"The current discount of 28 percent to net asset value on our share price is not justified. Nearly all our units are listed on the stock market. Our share price's discount, according to Belgian standards, should only amount to 15 percent," Liotier was quoted as saying in the magazine of the Flemish Investment Club Federation VFB.
At 1100 GMT SGB shares were quoted 2,880 francs, down 15.
Asked about what VFB said was slow dividend growth, Liotier said that last year's acquisition of an extra stake in its utilities unit Tractebel SA was weighing on SGB's cash streams.

"On the other hand, we have a payout ratio of 90 percent, which is why we cannot be as flexible with our dividend as other companies. Investors must also look at the rise of the share price," he said.
SGB said in October that there would be no decrease in the 1996 dividend following its 49 billion franc purchase of a 24.7 percent stake in Tractebel.
Last year, SGB paid 87 francs net per share on 1995 earnings.
SGB is 62.6 percent owned by Compagnie de Suez.
